item.title: Last Looks at the Pre-War World (1): America's Boom
item.description:
Like many of you, I have spent much of the past month trying to understand the implications of Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine. The war and its aftermath will have profound consequences for years, perhaps even moreso than the pandemic. In this next series of notes, however, I will focus on what the latest data releases‚Äîmost of which describe the world as of mid-February‚Äîtell us about economic conditions in the major economies‚Ä¶

URL: https://theovershoot.co/p/last-looks-at-the-pre-war-world-1?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: Glory Liu on the Adam Smith Americans Have Imagined, &

item.title: Imminent Death of the Academy Predicted
item.description:
Back when I was a sophomore at Williams, the sticker price broke twenty thousand dollars for the first time, and some angry person spray-painted the columns of Chapin Hall with the digits: $20,760. I remember a lot of agitated thinkpieces about the unsustainable trajectory of higher education in the US, and predicting that some sort of reckoning would n‚Ä¶

item.title: Lessons From Keynes For The Crisis In Ukraine
item.description:
I gave a talk at an IMF event on Tuesday alongside Douglas Holtz-Eakin and Francesco Saraceno. On the off-chance that some of the subscribers to this newsletter were unable to make the event, I‚Äôm posting my prepared remarks here. The IMF folks had asked for some historical insights from Keynes regarding policy options in a post-COVID world, but‚Ä¶
